metadata.synopsis: The touching story of a sailor (Derek Luke) who, prone to violent outbursts, is sent to a naval psychiatrist (Denzel Washington) for help. Refusing at first to open up, the young man eventually breaks down and reveals a horrific childhood. Through the guidance of his new doctor, he confronts his painful past and begins a quest to find the family he never knew.

reviews: There is such a thing as under-acting to a point where you exude the charisma of a plant pot. The directing goes the same way, plodding along conscientiously but without any spark -- one can sense the cameras splintering out of sheer boredom.
a very powerful drama that doesn't just tug at the heartstrings, but yanks them hard
Devastating story of abuse based on real life.
Rings false, belittling instead of honoring its sensitive subject with its twinkly score, kid-glove nobility and cloying payoffs. [Blu-ray]
It is to Washington's credit that he keeps it just real enough to move our hearts and our heads.
Sails the same route as dozens of Hollywood psychiatry dramas...Its power lies in the rich themes and performances.
The most remarkable thing about Antwone Fisher is the real-life story on which it is based.
Yes, Antwone Fisher is a good movie, in the way that lima beans are good food. You may leave the theater feeling fortified, but you'll have a bad taste in your mouth.
Soupy and sentimental, but with an underlying belief in itself that keeps the rhythm constant and just about manages to reach the gut.
For his directorial debut, Denzel Washington (has made) a haunting and resonant film covered with a potent Southern Gothic chill.
Has the capability of effecting change and inspiring hope.

Washington makes his directorial debut with Antwone Fisher, a fact-based biography that deftly pulls the heartstrings. Granted, it covers no new ground that other psychiatrist/patient films haven't gone before.
Antwone Fisher transforma sua prpria histria em uma lio de resistncia e humanidade.
. . .one of the year's most insightful and evocative films.
